citation.fr: [{\"type\": \"dataset\", \"id\": \"ca.cioos_a45b745e-a265-4316-aa53-ca5988e1c1ad\", \"author\": [{\"given\": \"Kyra\", \"family\": \"Janot\"}], \"issued\": [{\"date-parts\": [\"2024\", \"06\", \"12\"]}], \"abstract\": \"Ce jeu de donn\u00e9es est d\u00e9riv\u00e9 de relev\u00e9s en transects r\u00e9alis\u00e9s dans la zone intertidale de quatre sites de la r\u00e9gion m\u00e9tropolitaine de Vancouver en Colombie-Britannique\u00a0: Brockton Point, \u00e0 Vancouver\u00a0; Lighthouse Park, West Vancouver\u00a0; Crescent Beach, Surrey\u00a0; et Cates Park, \u00e0 North Vancouver. Chaque site a \u00e9t\u00e9 \u00e9tudi\u00e9 en juillet 2022, novembre 2022 et f\u00e9vrier 2023. \nPour chaque \u00e9tude, quatre lignes de transect verticales ont \u00e9t\u00e9 trac\u00e9es entre la zone intertidale haute et la ligne de mar\u00e9e \u00e0 mar\u00e9e basse, et des quadrats ont \u00e9t\u00e9 plac\u00e9s tous les 5 m. La hauteur de mar\u00e9e pour chaque quadrat a \u00e9t\u00e9 d\u00e9termin\u00e9e en fonction du niveau d'un g\u00e9om\u00e8tre et le type de substrat dans chaque quadrat a \u00e9t\u00e9 enregistr\u00e9. Le pourcentage de couverture de chaque esp\u00e8ce de macroalgues ou d'herbiers marins visuellement distincte a \u00e9t\u00e9 estim\u00e9 dans chaque quadrat; pour les esp\u00e8ces qui n'ont pas pu \u00eatre identifi\u00e9es sur le terrain, des \u00e9chantillons repr\u00e9sentatifs ont \u00e9t\u00e9 collect\u00e9s et analys\u00e9s en laboratoire \u00e0 l'aide d'une cl\u00e9 dichotomique ou d'un code-barres ADN. Les sp\u00e9cimens press\u00e9s ont re\u00e7u un num\u00e9ro de collection et ont \u00e9t\u00e9 d\u00e9pos\u00e9s \u00e0 l'herbier de l'Universit\u00e9 de la Colombie-Britannique. Des esp\u00e8ces uniques qui n'auraient pas \u00e9t\u00e9 observ\u00e9es autrement dans les quadrats ont \u00e9galement \u00e9t\u00e9 enregistr\u00e9es comme \u00e9tant pr\u00e9sentes \u00ab\u00a0hors du quadrat\u00a0\u00bb. Une combinaison de la hauteur des mar\u00e9es, de points de rep\u00e8re et de nombreuses photos du site et du quadrat a \u00e9t\u00e9 utilis\u00e9e pour s'assurer que les quadrats \u00e9taient plac\u00e9s au m\u00eame endroit lors de chacun des trois relev\u00e9s effectu\u00e9s sur un site donn\u00e9. \nL'objectif de ce projet est d'\u00e9tablir une base de r\u00e9f\u00e9rence pour la saisonnalit\u00e9 de diff\u00e9rentes esp\u00e8ces de macroalgues et d'herbiers marins sur diff\u00e9rents sites en ce qui concerne \u00e0 la fois leur abondance et leur distribution sur le rivage, en pr\u00e9vision des changements potentiels dans la structure des communaut\u00e9s li\u00e9s aux futurs changements climatiques et de l'utilisation des terres. Ce projet a \u00e9t\u00e9 financ\u00e9 par le Programme sur les donn\u00e9es environnementales c\u00f4ti\u00e8res de r\u00e9f\u00e9rence de P\u00eaches et Oc\u00e9ans Canada dans le cadre du Plan de protection des oc\u00e9ans, ainsi que par une subvention du Centre de recherche appliqu\u00e9e du Langara College.\", \"edition\": \"\", \"edition-date\": \"\", \"publisher\": \"\", \"title\": \"Relev\u00e9s saisonniers des algues marines dans la zone intertidale du Grand Vancouver\", \"DOI\": \"10.26071/ogsl-a45b745e-a265\", \"language\": \"fr\", \"URL\": \"https://catalogue.ogsl.ca/dataset/ca-cioos_a45b745e-a265-4316-aa53-ca5988e1c1ad?local=fr\"}]
citation.en: [{\"type\": \"dataset\", \"id\": \"ca.cioos_a45b745e-a265-4316-aa53-ca5988e1c1ad\", \"author\": [{\"given\": \"Kyra\", \"family\": \"Janot\"}], \"issued\": [{\"date-parts\": [\"2024\", \"06\", \"12\"]}], \"abstract\": \"This dataset is derived from transect surveys performed in the intertidal zone of four sites in the Greater Vancouver area of British Columbia: Brockton Point, Vancouver; Lighthouse Park, West Vancouver; Crescent Beach, Surrey; and Cates Park, North Vancouver. Each site was surveyed in July 2022, November 2022, and February 2023. \nFor each survey four vertical transect lines were laid out from the high intertidal to the tideline during low tide, and quadrats were laid down every 5 m. Tidal height for each quadrat was determined with a surveyor\u2019s level and substrate type within each quadrat was recorded. Percent cover of each visually distinct macroalgal or seagrass species was estimated within each quadrat; for species that could not be identified in the field, representative vouchers were collected and analysed in the lab using a dichotomous key or DNA barcoding. Pressed vouchers were assigned a collection number and deposited at the University of British Columbia Herbarium. Unique species that were not otherwise observed within quadrats were also recorded as present \\"out of quadrat\\". A combination of tidal height, landmarks, and extensive site/quadrat pictures was used to ensure that quadrats were placed in the same spot during each of the three surveys at a given site. \nThe goal of this project is to establish a baseline in the seasonality of different macroalgal/seagrass species at different sites with respect to both abundance and distribution on the shore, in anticipation of potential shifts in community structure related to future changes in climate and land use. It was funded via the Department of Fisheries and Oceans Canada's Coastal Environmental Baseline Program under the Oceans Protection Plan, as well as a grant from Langara College's Applied Research Centre.\", \"edition\": \"\", \"edition-date\": \"\", \"publisher\": \"\", \"title\": \"Seasonal Seaweed Diversity in the Intertidal Zone of Greater Vancouver\", \"DOI\": \"10.26071/ogsl-a45b745e-a265\", \"language\": \"en\", \"URL\": \"https://catalogue.ogsl.ca/dataset/ca-cioos_a45b745e-a265-4316-aa53-ca5988e1c1ad?local=en\"}]

      <mri:abstract xsi:type="lan:PT_FreeText_PropertyType">
        <gco:CharacterString>This dataset is derived from transect surveys performed in the intertidal zone of four sites in the Greater Vancouver area of British Columbia: Brockton Point, Vancouver; Lighthouse Park, West Vancouver; Crescent Beach, Surrey; and Cates Park, North Vancouver. Each site was surveyed in July 2022, November 2022, and February 2023. 
For each survey four vertical transect lines were laid out from the high intertidal to the tideline during low tide, and quadrats were laid down every 5 m. Tidal height for each quadrat was determined with a surveyor‚Äôs level and substrate type within each quadrat was recorded. Percent cover of each visually distinct macroalgal or seagrass species was estimated within each quadrat; for species that could not be identified in the field, representative vouchers were collected and analysed in the lab using a dichotomous key or DNA barcoding. Pressed vouchers were assigned a collection number and deposited at the University of British Columbia Herbarium. Unique species that were not otherwise observed within quadrats were also recorded as present "out of quadrat". A combination of tidal height, landmarks, and extensive site/quadrat pictures was used to ensure that quadrats were placed in the same spot during each of the three surveys at a given site. 
The goal of this project is to establish a baseline in the seasonality of different macroalgal/seagrass species at different sites with respect to both abundance and distribution on the shore, in anticipation of potential shifts in community structure related to future changes in climate and land use. It was funded via the Department of Fisheries and Oceans Canada's Coastal Environmental Baseline Program under the Oceans Protection Plan, as well as a grant from Langara College's Applied Research Centre.</gco:CharacterString>

La hauteur de mar√©e pour chaque quadrat a √©t√© d√©termin√©e en fonction du niveau d'un g√©om√®tre et le type de substrat dans chaque quadrat a √©t√© enregistr√©. Le pourcentage de couverture de chaque esp√®ce de macroalgues ou d'herbiers marins visuellement distincte a √©t√© estim√© dans chaque quadrat; pour les esp√®ces qui n'ont pas pu √™tre identifi√©es sur le terrain, des √©chantillons repr√©sentatifs ont √©t√© collect√©s et analys√©s en laboratoire √† l'aide d'une cl√© dichotomique ou d'un code-barres ADN. Composition et couverture des herbiers marins

name: ca-cioos_a45b745e-a265-4316-aa53-ca5988e1c1ad
notes:
This dataset is derived from transect surveys performed in the intertidal zone of four sites in the Greater Vancouver area of British Columbia: Brockton Point, Vancouver; Lighthouse Park, West Vancouver; Crescent Beach, Surrey; and Cates Park, North Vancouver. Each site was surveyed in July 2022, November 2022, and February 2023. 
For each survey four vertical transect lines were laid out from the high intertidal to the tideline during low tide, and quadrats were laid down every 5 m. Tidal height for each quadrat was determined with a surveyor‚Äôs level and substrate type within each quadrat was recorded. Percent cover of each visually distinct macroalgal or seagrass species was estimated within each quadrat; for species that could not be identified in the field, representative vouchers were collected and analysed in the lab using a dichotomous key or DNA barcoding. Pressed vouchers were assigned a collection number and deposited at the University of British Columbia Herbarium. Unique species that were not otherwise observed within quadrats were also recorded as present "out of quadrat". A combination of tidal height, landmarks, and extensive site/quadrat pictures was used to ensure that quadrats were placed in the same spot during each of the three surveys at a given site. 
The goal of this project is to establish a baseline in the seasonality of different macroalgal/seagrass species at different sites with respect to both abundance and distribution on the shore, in anticipation of potential shifts in community structure related to future changes in climate and land use. It was funded via the Department of Fisheries and Oceans Canada's Coastal Environmental Baseline Program under the Oceans Protection Plan, as well as a grant from Langara College's Applied Research Centre.

description_translated.en:
Created in 2005 by federal and provincial government as well as academic institutions and community organizations, the St. Lawrence Global Observatory (SLGO) makes it possible to maximize the benefits of data collection by integrating multidisciplinary data from multiple partners on a single web portal. Promoting data discovery and re-use, SLGO counts 48 members and is recognized throughout the world.

The content distributed by SLGO spans across all disciplines, themes and areas of interest that data-producing members choose to make accessible. A large amount of scientific and environmental information is already available through SLGO's portal. Furthermore, in order to maximize data availability, SLGO's team develops user-friendly web applications to facilitate data visualization and download in various formats.

SLGO is, as such, responsible for the activities of the region of the St. Lawrence of CIOOS. To contribute, we invite you to contact us.
